3    |  ** 									     **
4    |  **   Modules Revision 3.0						     **
5    |  **   Providing a flexible user environment				     **
6    |  ** 									     **
7    |  **   File:		getopt.c					     **
8    |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **
9    |  ** 									     **

11   |  ** 									     **
12   |  **   Description:	getopt procedure for the Modules package	     **
13   |  ** 									     **
14   |  **   Exports:		getopt		Recognition of commadn line options  **
15   |  ** 									     **
16   |  **   Notes: This is based on the 'Getopt for GNU' from the gcc-2.7.2        **
17   |  **          compiler. It is preferred to the libc version, because it       **
18   |  **	     provides 'long-options'.					     **
19   |  **									     **

57   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
58   | /** 				   CONFIGURATION			     **/
59   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
60   | 
61   | /**
62   |  **  This tells Alpha OSF/1 not to define a getopt prototype in <stdio.h>.
63   |  **  Ditto for AIX 3.2 and <stdlib.h>.
64   |  **/
65   | 
66   | #ifndef _NO_PROTO
67   | #  define _NO_PROTO
68   | #endif
69   | 
70   | #ifdef HAVE_CONFIG_H
71   | #  include <config.h>
72   | #endif
73   | 
74   | /**
75   |  **  This is a separate conditional since some stdc systems
76   |  **  reject `defined( const)'. 
77   |  **/
78   | 
79   | #if !defined( __STDC__) || !__STDC__
80   | #  ifndef const
81   | #    define const
82   | #  endif
83   | #endif
84   | 
85   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
86   | /** 				      HEADERS				     **/
87   | /** ************************************************************************ **/
88   | 
89   | #include <stdio.h>
90   | 
91   | /**
92   |  **  Comment out all this code if we are using the GNU C Library, and are not
93   |  **  actually compiling the library itself.  This code is part of the GNU C
94   |  **  Library, but also included in many other GNU distributions.  Compiling
95   |  **  and linking in this code is a waste when using the GNU C library
96   |  ** ( especially if it is a shared library).  Rather than having every GNU
97   |  **  program understand `configure --with-gnu-libc' and omit the object files,
98   |  **  it is simpler to just do this in the source for each such file. 
99   |  **
100  |  ** All this conditional nonsense has been commented out, because this
101  |  ** version of getopt has some module specific error handling that gets
102  |  ** tested during the check.  It's a nice sentiment, but it doesn't buy
103  |  ** you much to not include this code in.
104  |  **/
105  | 
106  | /**
107  |  **  This needs to come after some library #include
108  |  **  to get __GNU_LIBRARY__ defined. 
109  |  **/
110  | 
111  | /* #if defined( _LIBC) || !defined (__GNU_LIBRARY__) */
112  | 
113  | /**
114  |  **  Don't include stdlib.h for non-GNU C libraries because some of them
115  |  **  contain conflicting prototypes for getopt. 
116  |  **/
117  | 
118  | #  ifdef	__GNU_LIBRARY__
119  | #    include <stdlib.h>
120  | #  endif	/* GNU C library.  */
121  | 
122  | /**
123  |  **  This is for other GNU distributions with internationalized messages.
124  |  **  When compiling libc, the _ macro is predefined. 
125  |  **/
126  | 
127  | /*
128  | #  ifndef _
129  | #    ifdef HAVE_LIBINTL_H
130  | #     include <libintl.h>
131  | #     define _(msgid)	gettext( msgid)
132  | #    else
133  | #     define _(msgid)	(msgid)
134  | #    endif
135  | #  endif
136  | */
137  | 
138  | /**
139  |  **  This version of `getopt' appears to the caller like standard Unix `getopt'
140  |  **  but it behaves differently for the user, since it allows the user
141  |  **  to intersperse the options with the other arguments.
142  |  **
143  |  **  As `getopt' works, it permutes the elements of ARGV so that,
144  |  **  when it is done, all the options precede everything else.  Thus
145  |  **  all application programs are extended to handle flexible argument order.
146  |  **
147  |  **  Setting the environment variable POSIXLY_CORRECT disables permutation.
148  |  **  Then the behavior is completely standard.
149  |  **
150  |  **  GNU application programs can use a third alternative mode in which
151  |  **  they can distinguish the relative order of options and other arguments. 
152  |  **/
153  | 
154  | #  include "getopt.h"
155  | 
156  | /**
157  |  **  We want to avoid inclusion of string.h with non-GNU libraries
158  |  **  because there are many ways it can cause trouble.
159  |  **  On some systems, it contains special magic macros that don't work
160  |  **  in GCC. 
161  |  **/
162  | 
163  | #  ifdef	__GNU_LIBRARY__
164  | #    include <string.h>
165  | #    define	my_index	strchr
166  | #  else
167  | 
168  | /**
169  |  **  Avoid depending on library functions or files whose names are
170  |  **  inconsistent. 
171  |  **/
172  | 
173  | char *getenv();
174  | 
175  | static char *my_index( const char *str, int chr)
176  | {
177  |     while( *str) {
178  | 	if( *str == chr)
179  | 	    return( char *) str;
180  | 	str++;
181  |     }
182  |     return( 0);
183  | }
184  | 
185  | /**
186  |  **  If using GCC, we can safely declare strlen this way. 
187  |  **  If not using GCC, it is ok not to declare it. 
188  |  **
189  |  **  Note that Motorola Delta 68k R3V7 comes with GCC but not stddef.h.
190  |  **  That was relevant to code that was here before.
191  |  **/
192  | 
193  | #    ifdef __GNUC__
194  | #      if !defined( __STDC__) || !__STDC__
195  | 
196  | /**
197  |  **  gcc with -traditional declares the built-in strlen to return int,
198  |  **  and has done so at least since version 2.4.5. -- rms. 
199  |  **/
200  | 
201  | extern int strlen( const char *);
202  | #      endif /* not __STDC__ */
203  | #    endif /* __GNUC__ */
204  | 
205  | #  endif /* not __GNU_LIBRARY__ */
206  | 
207  | /**
208  |  **  Include the modules header in order to get all error messages
209  |  **/
210  | 
211  | #include "modules_def.h"
212  | 
213  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
214  | /** 				  LOCAL DATATYPES			     **/
215  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
216  | 
217  | /** not applicable **/
218  | 
219  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
220  | /** 				     CONSTANTS				     **/
221  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
222  | 
223  | /** not applicable **/
224  | 
225  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
226  | /**				      MACROS				     **/
227  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
228  | 
229  | /** not applicable **/
230  | 
231  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
232  | /** 				    GLOBAL DATA				     **/
233  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
234  | 
235  | /**
236  |  **  The following is required for compiling the TEST environment for the
237  |  **  modules package
238  |  **/
239  | 
240  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
241  | #  ifdef	TEST
242  | char	*g_current_module = "getopt";
243  | int	linenum = 0;
244  | #  endif
245  | #endif /** _MODULES_DEF_H **/
246  | 
247  | /**
248  |  **  For communication from `getopt' to the caller.  When `getopt' finds an
249  |  **  option that takes an argument, the argument value is returned here.
250  |  **  Also, when `ordering' is RETURN_IN_ORDER, each non-option ARGV-element
251  |  **  is returned here. 
252  |  **/
253  | 
254  | char *optarg = NULL;
255  | 
256  | /**
257  |  **  Index in ARGV of the next element to be scanned.  This is used for
258  |  **  communication to and from the caller and for communication between
259  |  **  successive calls to `getopt'.
260  |  **
261  |  **  On entry to `getopt', zero means this is the first call; initialize.
262  |  **
263  |  **  When `getopt' returns EOF, this is the index of the first of the
264  |  **  non-option elements that the caller should itself scan.
265  |  **
266  |  **  Otherwise, `optind' communicates from one call to the next
267  |  **  how much of ARGV has been scanned so far. 
268  |  **/
269  | 
270  | /**
271  |  **  XXX 1003.2 says this must be 1 before any call. 
272  |  **/
273  | 
274  | int optind = 0;
275  | 
276  | /**
277  |  **  Callers store zero here to inhibit the error message for unrecognized
278  |  **  options. 
279  |  **/
280  | 
281  | int opterr = 1;
282  | 
283  | /**
284  |  **  Set to an option character which was unrecognized.
285  |  **  This must be initialized on some systems to avoid linking in the
286  |  **  system's own getopt implementation. 
287  |  **/
288  | 
289  | int optopt = '?';
290  | 
291  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
292  | /** 				    LOCAL DATA				     **/
293  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
294  | 
295  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
296  | 
297  | /**
298  |  **  Runtime information for the modules package
299  |  **/
300  | 
301  | static	char	module_name[] = __FILE__;
302  | 
303  | #ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
304  | #  if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
305  | static	char	_proc_exchange[] = "exchange";
306  | static	char	_proc_getopt_initialize[] = "_getopt_initialize";
307  | static	char	_proc_getopt_internal[] = " _getopt_internal";
308  | static	char	_proc_getopt[] = "getopt";
309  | static	char	_proc_getopt_long[] = "getopt_long";
310  | static	char	_proc_getopt_long_only[] = "getopt_long_only";
311  | #  endif
312  | #endif
313  | 
314  | #  ifdef	TEST
315  | static	char	_proc_main[] = "main";
316  | #  endif
317  | 
318  | #endif /** _MODULES_DEF_H **/
319  | 
320  | /**
321  |  **  The next char to be scanned in the option-element in which the last
322  |  **  option character we returned was found.  This allows us to pick up
323  |  **  the scan where we left off.
324  |  **
325  |  **  If this is zero, or a null string, it means resume the scan by advan-
326  |  **  cing to the next ARGV-element. 
327  |  **/
328  | 
329  | static char *nextchar;
330  | 
331  | /**
332  |  **  Describe how to deal with options that follow non-option ARGV-elements.
333  |  **
334  |  **  If the caller did not specify anything, the default is REQUIRE_ORDER if
335  |  **  the environment variable POSIXLY_CORRECT is defined, PERMUTE otherwise.
336  |  **
337  |  **  REQUIRE_ORDER means don't recognize them as options;
338  |  **  stop option processing when the first non-option is seen.
339  |  **  This is what Unix does.
340  |  **  This mode of operation is selected by either setting the environment
341  |  **  variable POSIXLY_CORRECT, or using `+' as the first character
342  |  **  of the list of option characters.
343  |  **
344  |  **  PERMUTE is the default.  We permute the contents of ARGV as we scan,
345  |  **  so that eventually all the non-options are at the end.  This allows options
346  |  **  to be given in any order, even with programs that were not written to
347  |  **  expect this.
348  |  **
349  |  **  RETURN_IN_ORDER is an option available to programs that were written
350  |  **  to expect options and other ARGV-elements in any order and that care about
351  |  **  the ordering of the two.  We describe each non-option ARGV-element
352  |  **  as if it were the argument of an option with character code 1.
353  |  **  Using `-' as the first character of the list of option characters
354  |  **  selects this mode of operation.
355  |  **
356  |  **  The special argument `--' forces an end of option-scanning regardless
357  |  **  of the value of `ordering'.  In the case of RETURN_IN_ORDER, only
358  |  **  `--' can cause `getopt' to return EOF with `optind' != ARGC. 
359  |  **/
360  | 
361  | static enum {
362  |     REQUIRE_ORDER, PERMUTE, RETURN_IN_ORDER
363  | } ordering;
364  | 
365  | /**
366  |  **  Value of POSIXLY_CORRECT environment variable. 
367  |  **/
368  | 
369  | static char *posixly_correct;
370  | 
371  | /**
372  |  **  Handle permutation of arguments. 
373  |  **/
374  | 
375  | /**
376  |  **  Describe the part of ARGV that contains non-options that have
377  |  **  been skipped.  `first_nonopt' is the index in ARGV of the first of them;
378  |  **  `last_nonopt' is the index after the last of them. 
379  |  **/
380  | 
381  | static int first_nonopt;
382  | static int last_nonopt;
383  | 
384  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
385  | /**				    PROTOTYPES				     **/
386  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
387  | 
388  | static void exchange( char **argv);
389  | static const char *_getopt_initialize( const char *optstring);
390  | static	int _getopt_internal(	int			 argc,
391  | 				char *const	 	*argv,
392  | 				const char	 	*optstring,
393  | 				const struct option	*longopts,
394  | 				int			*longind,
395  | 				int			 long_only);
396  | 
397  | /*++++
398  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
399  |  ** 									     **
400  |  **   Function:		exchange					     **
401  |  ** 									     **
402  |  **   Description:	Exchange two adjacent subsequences of ARGV.	     **
403  |  **			One subsequence is elements( first_nonopt,	     **
404  |  **			last_nonopt) which contains all the non-options that **
405  |  **			have been skipped so far. The other is elements	     **
406  |  **			(last_nonopt,optind), which contains all the options **
407  |  **			processed since those non-options were skipped.	     **
408  |  **									     **
409  |  **  			`first_nonopt' and `last_nonopt' are relocated so    **
410  |  **			that they describe the new indices of the non-options**
411  |  **			in ARGV after they are moved. 			     **
412  |  ** 									     **
413  |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **
414  |  ** 									     **
415  |  **   Parameters:	char	**argv		Command line arguments	     **
416  |  ** 									     **
417  |  **   Result:		argv		ARGV array with exchanged sequences  **
418  |  ** 									     **
419  |  **   Attached Globals:	first_nonopt	first and last non option argument   **
420  |  **			last_nonopt	on the stream before and after the   **
421  |  **					change.( I/O parameter)		     **
422  |  ** 									     **
423  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
424  |  ++++*/
425  | 
426  | static void exchange( char **argv)
427  | {
428  |     int bottom = first_nonopt;
429  |     int middle = last_nonopt;
430  |     int top = optind;
431  |     char *tem;
432  | 
433  | #ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
434  | #  if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
435  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_exchange, NULL);
436  | #  endif
437  | #endif
438  | 
439  |     /**
440  |      **  Exchange the shorter segment with the far end of the longer segment.
441  |      **  That puts the shorter segment into the right place.
442  |      **  It leaves the longer segment in the right place overall,
443  |      **  but it consists of two parts that need to be swapped next. 
444  |      **/
445  | 
446  |     while( top > middle && middle > bottom) {
447  | 	if( top - middle > middle - bottom) {
448  | 
449  | 	    /**
450  | 	     ** Bottom segment is the short one. 
451  | 	     **/
452  | 
453  | 	    int len = middle - bottom;
454  | 	    register int i;
455  | 
456  | 	    /**
457  | 	     **  Swap it with the top part of the top segment. 
458  | 	     **/
459  | 
460  | 	    for( i = 0; i < len; i++) {
461  | 		tem = argv[bottom + i];
462  | 		argv[bottom + i] = argv[top -( middle - bottom) + i];
463  | 		argv[top -( middle - bottom) + i] = tem;
464  | 	    }
465  | 
466  | 	    /**
467  | 	     **  Exclude the moved bottom segment from further swapping. 
468  | 	     **/
469  | 
470  | 	    top -= len;
471  | 
472  | 	} else {
473  | 	    
474  | 	    /**
475  | 	     **  Top segment is the short one. 
476  | 	     **/
477  | 
478  | 	    int len = top - middle;
479  | 	    register int i;
480  | 
481  | 	    /**
482  | 	     **  Swap it with the bottom part of the bottom segment. 
483  | 	     **/
484  | 
485  | 	    for( i = 0; i < len; i++) {
486  | 		tem = argv[bottom + i];
487  | 		argv[bottom + i] = argv[middle + i];
488  | 		argv[middle + i] = tem;
489  | 	    }
490  | 
491  | 	    /**
492  | 	     **  Exclude the moved top segment from further swapping. 
493  | 	     **/
494  | 
495  | 	    bottom += len;
496  | 	}
497  | 
498  |     } /** while **/
499  | 
500  |     /**
501  |      **  Update records for the slots the non-options now occupy. 
502  |      **/
503  | 
504  |     first_nonopt +=( optind - last_nonopt);
505  |     last_nonopt = optind;
506  | 
507  | #ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
508  | #  if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
509  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_END, LOC, _proc_exchange, NULL);
510  | #  endif
511  | #endif
512  | 
513  | } /** end of 'exchange' **/
514  | 
515  | /*++++
516  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
517  |  ** 									     **
518  |  **   Function:		_getopt_initialize				     **
519  |  ** 									     **
520  |  **   Description:	Initialize the internal data when the first call is  **
521  |  **			made						     **
522  |  **			This defines how to proceed if options and non-op-   **
523  |  **			tions are mixed up. See definition of the enum       **
524  |  **			'ordering' for further explanation.		     **
525  |  ** 									     **
526  |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **
527  |  ** 									     **
528  |  **   Parameters:	char	*optstring	Options string		     **
529  |  ** 									     **
530  |  **   Result:		argv		ARGV array with exchanged sequences  **
531  |  **									     **
532  |  **   Attached globals: first_nonopt,		First an las position of     **
533  |  **			last_nonopt		non-option arguments	     **
534  |  **			optind			Option scan index	     **
535  |  **			nextchar		Next character to scan	     **
536  |  **			posixly_correct		Value of the environment     **
537  |  **						variable 'POSIXLY_CORRECT'   **
538  |  **			ordering		Ordering method ...	     **
539  |  ** 									     **
540  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
541  |  ++++*/
542  | 
543  | static const char *_getopt_initialize( const char *optstring)
544  | {
545  | 
546  | #ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
547  | #  if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
548  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_getopt_initialize, NULL);
549  | #  endif
550  | #endif
551  | 
552  |     /**
553  |      **  Start processing options with ARGV-element 1( since ARGV-element 0
554  |      **  is the program name); the sequence of previously skipped
555  |      **  non-option ARGV-elements is empty. 
556  |      **/
557  | 
558  |     first_nonopt = last_nonopt = optind = 1;
559  |     nextchar = NULL;
560  |     posixly_correct = getenv( "POSIXLY_CORRECT");
561  | 
562  |     /**
563  |      **  Determine how to handle the ordering of options and nonoptions. 
564  |      **/
565  | 
566  |     if( optstring[0] == '-') {
567  | 	ordering = RETURN_IN_ORDER;
568  | 	++optstring;
569  | 
570  |     } else if( optstring[0] == '+') {
571  | 	ordering = REQUIRE_ORDER;
572  | 	++optstring;
573  | 
574  |     } else if( posixly_correct != NULL)
575  | 	ordering = REQUIRE_ORDER;
576  | 
577  |     else
578  | 	ordering = PERMUTE;
579  | 
580  | #ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
581  | #  if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
582  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_END, LOC, _proc_getopt_initialize, NULL);
583  | #  endif
584  | #endif
585  | 
586  |     return( optstring);
587  | 
588  | } /** End of '_getopt_initialize' **/
589  | 
590  | /*++++
591  |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
592  |  ** 									     **
593  |  **   Function:		_getopt_internal				     **
594  |  ** 									     **
595  |  **   Description:	Scan elements of ARGV( whose length is ARGC) for     **
596  |  **			option characters given in OPTSTRING.	  	     **
597  |  **			or long-options specified in the longopt array	     **
598  |  ** 									     **
599  |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **
600  |  ** 									     **
601  |  **   Parameters:	int		  argc,		# of arguments	     **
602  |  **			char		**argv,		ARGV array	     **
603  |  **			char	 	 *optstring,	String of valid      **
604  |  **							short options	     **
605  |  **			struct option	 *longopts,	Table of valid long  **
606  |  **							options		     **
607  |  **			int		 *longind,	Returns the index of **
608  |  **							the found long opt.  **
609  |  **			int		  long_only	Search long options  **
610  |  **							only		     **
611  |  ** 									     **
612  |  **   Result:		int	'?'	Parse error			     **
613  |  **				0	Long option w/o argument found	     **
614  |  **				else	short option that has been found     **
615  |  **					or the value of a long option	     **
616  |  **				EOF	no more arguments on ARGV	     **
617  |  **									     **
618  |  **   Attached globals:	optind		Index of the current option in the   **
619  |  **					ARGV array			     **
620  |  **			optarg		Argument of an option with value     **
621  |  **									     **
622  |  ** ************************************************************************ **
623  |  ++++*/
624  | /** 									     **/
625  | /**   If an element of ARGV starts with '-', and is not exactly "-" or "--", **/
626  | /**   then it is an option element.  The characters of this element 	     **/
627  | /**   ( aside from the initial '-') are option characters.  If `getopt'      **/
628  | /**   is called repeatedly, it returns successively each of the option 	     **/
629  | /**   characters from each of the option elements. 			     **/
630  | /** 									     **/
631  | /**   If `getopt' finds another option character, it returns that character, **/
632  | /**   updating `optind' and `nextchar' so that the next call to `getopt' can **/
633  | /**   resume the scan with the following option character or ARGV-element.   **/
634  | /** 									     **/
635  | /**   If there are no more option characters, `getopt' returns `EOF'. 	     **/
636  | /**   Then `optind' is the index in ARGV of the first ARGV-element 	     **/
637  | /**   that is not an option. ( The ARGV-elements have been permuted 	     **/
638  | /**   so that those that are not options now come last.) 		     **/
639  | /** 									     **/
640  | /**   OPTSTRING is a string containing the legitimate option characters.     **/
641  | /**   If an option character is seen that is not listed in OPTSTRING, 	     **/
642  | /**   return '?' after printing an error message.  If you set `opterr' to    **/
643  | /**   zero, the error message is suppressed but we still return '?'. 	     **/
644  | /** 									     **/
645  | /**   If a char in OPTSTRING is followed by a colon, that means it wants an  **/
646  | /**   arg, so the following text in the same ARGV-element, or the text of    **/
647  | /**   the following ARGV-element, is returned in `optarg'.  Two colons mean  **/
648  | /**   an option that wants an optional arg; if there is text in the current  **/
649  | /**   ARGV-element, it is returned in `optarg', otherwise `optarg' is set to **/
650  | /**   zero. 								     **/
651  | /** 									     **/
652  | /**   If OPTSTRING starts with `-' or `+', it requests different methods of  **/
653  | /**   handling the non-option ARGV-elements. 				     **/
654  | /**   See the comments about RETURN_IN_ORDER and REQUIRE_ORDER, above. 	     **/
655  | /** 									     **/
656  | /**   Long-named options begin with `--' instead of `-'. 		     **/
657  | /**   Their names may be abbreviated as long as the abbreviation is unique   **/
658  | /**   or is an exact match for some defined option.  If they have an 	     **/
659  | /**   argument, it follows the option name in the same ARGV-element, 	     **/
660  | /**   separated from the option name by a `=', or else the in next ARGV-     **/
661  | /**   element.  When `getopt' finds a long-named option, it returns 0 if     **/
662  | /**   that option's `flag' field is nonzero, the value of the option's `val' **/
663  | /**   field if the `flag' field is zero. 				     **/
664  | /** 									     **/
665  | /**   The elements of ARGV aren't really const, because we permute them.     **/
666  | /**   But we pretend they're const in the prototype to be compatible 	     **/
667  | /**   with other systems. 						     **/
668  | /** 									     **/
669  | /**   LONGOPTS is a vector of `struct option' terminated by an 	  	     **/
670  | /**   element containing a name which is zero. 				     **/
671  | /** 									     **/
672  | /**   LONGIND returns the index in LONGOPT of the long-named option found.   **/
673  | /**   It is only valid when a long-named option has been found by the most   **/
674  | /**   recent call. 							     **/
675  | /** 									     **/
676  | /**   If LONG_ONLY is nonzero, '-' as well as '--' can introduce 	     **/
677  | /**   long-named options.  						     **/
678  | /** 									     **/
679  | /** ************************************************************************ **/
680  | 
681  | static	int _getopt_internal(	int			 argc,
682  | 				char *const	 	*argv,
683  | 				const char	 	*optstring,
684  | 				const struct option	*longopts,
685  | 				int			*longind,
686  | 				int			 long_only)
687  | {
688  |     optarg = NULL;
689  | 
690  | #ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
691  | #  if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
692  |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_getopt_internal, NULL);
693  | #  endif
694  | #endif
695  | 
696  |     /**
697  |      **  Initialization
698  |      **/
699  | 
700  |     if( optind == 0) {
701  | 	optstring = _getopt_initialize( optstring);
702  | 	optind = 1;		/** Don't scan ARGV[0], the program name.    **/
703  |     }
704  | 
705  |     if( nextchar == NULL || *nextchar == '\0') {
706  | 
707  | 	/**
708  | 	 **  Advance to the next ARGV-element.
709  | 	 **/
710  | 
711  | 	if( ordering == PERMUTE) {
712  | 
713  | 	    /**
714  | 	     **  If we have just processed some options following some non-
715  | 	     **  options, exchange them so that the options come first. 
716  | 	     **/
717  | 
718  | 	    if( first_nonopt != last_nonopt && last_nonopt != optind)
719  | 		exchange( (char **) argv);
720  | 	    else if( last_nonopt != optind)
721  | 		first_nonopt = optind;
722  | 
723  | 	    /**
724  | 	     **  Skip any additional non-options and extend the range of
725  | 	     **  non-options previously skipped. 
726  | 	     **/
727  | 
728  | 	    while( optind < argc &&
729  | 		  ( argv[optind][0] != '-' || argv[optind][1] == '\0'))
730  | 		optind++;
731  | 
732  | 	    last_nonopt = optind;
733  | 	}
734  | 
735  | 	/**
736  | 	 **  The special ARGV-element `--' means premature end of options.
737  | 	 **  Skip it like a null option, then exchange with previous non-
738  | 	 **  options **  as if it were an option, then skip everything else
739  | 	 **  like a non-option. 
740  | 	 **/
741  | 
742  | 	if( optind != argc && !strcmp( argv[optind], "--")) {
743  | 
744  | 	    optind++;
745  | 
746  | 	    if( first_nonopt != last_nonopt && last_nonopt != optind)
747  | 		exchange((char **) argv);
748  | 	    else if( first_nonopt == last_nonopt)
749  | 		first_nonopt = optind;
750  | 
751  | 	    last_nonopt = argc;
752  | 
753  | 	    optind = argc;
754  | 	}
755  | 
756  | 	/**
757  | 	 **  If we have done all the ARGV-elements, stop the scan and back
758  | 	 **  over any non-options that we skipped and permuted. 
759  | 	 **/
760  | 
761  | 	if( optind == argc) {
762  | 
763  | 	    /**
764  | 	     **  Set the next-arg-index to point at the non-options that we
765  | 	     **  previously skipped, so the caller will digest them. 
766  | 	     **/
767  | 
768  | 	    if( first_nonopt != last_nonopt)
769  | 		optind = first_nonopt;
770  | 
771  | 	    return( EOF);
772  | 	}
773  | 
774  | 	/**
775  | 	 **  If we have come to a non-option and did not permute it,
776  | 	 **  either stop the scan or describe it to the caller and pass it by. 
777  | 	 **/
778  | 
779  | 	if( argv[optind][0] != '-' || argv[optind][1] == '\0') {
780  | 
781  | 	    if( ordering == REQUIRE_ORDER)
782  | 		return EOF;
783  | 	    optarg = argv[optind++];
784  | 
785  | 	    return( 1);
786  | 	}
787  | 
788  | 	/**
789  | 	 **  We have found another option-ARGV-element. 
790  | 	 **  Skip the initial punctuation. 
791  | 	 **/
792  | 
793  | 	nextchar =( argv[optind] + 1 +
794  | 	   ( longopts != NULL && argv[optind][1] == '-'));
795  |     }
796  | 
797  |     /**
798  |      **    Decode the current option-ARGV-element. 
799  |      **/
800  | 
801  |     /**
802  |      **  Check whether the ARGV-element is a long option.
803  |      **
804  |      **  If long_only and the ARGV-element has the form "-f", where f is
805  |      **  a valid short option, don't consider it an abbreviated form of
806  |      **  a long option that starts with f.  Otherwise there would be no
807  |      **  way to give the -f short option.
808  |      **
809  |      **  On the other hand, if there's a long option "fubar" and
810  |      **  the ARGV-element is "-fu", do consider that an abbreviation of
811  |      **  the long option, just like "--fu", and not "-f" with arg "u".
812  |      **
813  |      **  This distinction seems to be the most useful approach. 
814  |      **/
815  | 
816  |     if( longopts != NULL &&( argv[optind][1] == '-'     ||
817  |        (  long_only &&
818  | 	 (  argv[optind][2] || !my_index (optstring, argv[optind][1]))))) {
819  | 
820  | 	char *nameend;
821  | 	const struct option *p;
822  | 	const struct option *pfound = NULL;
823  | 	int exact = 0;
824  | 	int ambig = 0;
825  | 	int indfound;
826  | 	int option_index;
827  | 
828  | 	/**
829  | 	 **  Skip the remaining characters of the long option upt to its
830  | 	 **  names end( End of the option itsself or the '=' sign)
831  | 	 **/
832  | 
833  | 	for( nameend = nextchar; *nameend && *nameend != '='; nameend++);
834  | 
835  | 	/**
836  | 	 **  Test all long options for either exact match or abbreviated
837  | 	 **  matches.
838  | 	 **/
839  | 
840  | 	for( p = longopts, option_index = 0; p->name; p++, option_index++) {
841  | 	    if( !strncmp( p->name, nextchar, nameend - nextchar)) {
842  | 
843  | 		if( nameend - nextchar == strlen( p->name)) {
844  | 
845  | 		    /**
846  | 		     ** Exact match found. 
847  | 		     **/
848  | 
849  | 		    pfound = p;
850  | 		    indfound = option_index;
851  | 		    exact = 1;
852  | 		    break;
853  | 
854  | 		} else if( pfound == NULL) {
855  | 
856  | 		    /**
857  | 		     **  First nonexact match found.
858  | 		     **/
859  | 
860  | 		    pfound = p;
861  | 		    indfound = option_index;
862  | 
863  | 		} else
864  | 
865  | 		    /**
866  | 		     **  Second or later nonexact match found. 
867  | 		     **/
868  | 
869  | 		    ambig = 1;
870  | 
871  | 	    } /** if( !strncmp) **/
872  | 	} /** for **/
873  | 
874  | 	/**
875  | 	 **  Print an error message for ambigious abbreviations and exit
876  | 	 **  on error
877  | 	 **/
878  | 
879  | 	if( ambig && !exact) {
880  | 
881  | 	    if( opterr)
882  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
883  | 		ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_AMBIG, LOC, argv[optind], NULL);
884  | #else
885  | 		fprintf( stderr, _("%s: option `%s' is ambiguous\n"),
886  | 		    argv[0], argv[optind]);
887  | #endif
888  | 
889  | 	    nextchar += strlen( nextchar);
890  | 	    optind++;
891  | 	    return( '?');
892  | 	}
893  | 
894  | 	/**
895  | 	 **  Longname found ?
896  | 	 **/
897  | 
898  | 	if( pfound != NULL) {
899  | 
900  | 	    option_index = indfound;
901  | 	    optind++;
902  | 
903  | 	    /**
904  | 	     **  *nameend is != NULL if there is a value specified for
905  | 	     **  the option: '--option=value' -> *nameend = '='
906  | 	     **/
907  | 
908  | 	    if( *nameend) {
909  | 
910  | 		/**
911  | 		 **  Don't test has_arg with >, because some C compilers don't
912  | 		 **  allow it to be used on enums. 
913  | 		 **/
914  | 
915  | 		if( pfound->has_arg)
916  | 		    optarg = nameend + 1;
917  | 
918  | 		else {
919  | 		    	  
920  | 		    if( opterr) {
921  | 
922  | 			/**
923  | 			 **  ERROR: --option w/o argument
924  | 			 **/
925  | 
926  | 			if( argv[optind - 1][1] == '-')
927  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
928  | 			    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_NOARG, LOC, pfound->name, NULL);
929  | #else
930  | 			    fprintf( stderr,
931  | 				_("%s: option `--%s' doesn't allow an argument\n"),
932  | 				argv[0], pfound->name);
933  | #endif
934  | 
935  | 			/**
936  | 			 **  ERROR: +option or -option w/o argument
937  | 			 **/
938  | 
939  | 			} else {
940  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
941  | 			    char buffer[ BUFSIZ];
942  | 			    sprintf( buffer, "%c%s", argv[optind - 1][0], pfound->name);
943  | 			    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_NOARG, LOC, buffer, NULL);
944  | #else
945  | 			    fprintf( stderr,
946  | 				_("%s: option `%c%s' doesn't allow an argument\n"),
947  | 				argv[0], argv[optind - 1][0], pfound->name);
948  | #endif
949  | 			}
950  | 
951  | 		    nextchar += strlen( nextchar);
952  | 		    return( '?');
953  | 		}
954  | 
955  | 	    /**
956  | 	     **  Options with arguments
957  | 	     **/
958  | 
959  | 	    } else if( pfound->has_arg == 1) {
960  | 
961  | 		if( optind < argc)
962  | 		    optarg = argv[optind++];
963  | 
964  | 		else {
965  | 
966  | 		    /**
967  | 		     **  ERROR: Option without argument where one is required
968  | 		     **/
969  | 
970  | 		    if( opterr)
971  | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
972  | 			ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_REQARG, LOC, argv[optind-1], NULL);
973  | #else
974  | 			fprintf( stderr,
975  | 			    _("%s: option `%s' requires an argument\n"),
976  | 			    argv[0], argv[optind - 1]);
977  | #endif
978  | 
979  | 		    nextchar += strlen( nextchar);
980  | 		    return((optstring[0] == ':') ? ':' : '?');
981  | 		}
982  | 	    }
983  | 
984  | 	    /** 
985  | 	     **  Return the indication, that a long vlaue has been found
986  | 	     **  and set up pointers for the next option expansion
987  | 	     **/
988  | 
989  | 	    nextchar += strlen( nextchar);
990  | 
991  | 	    if( longind != NULL)
992  | 		*longind = option_index;
993  | 
994  | 	    if( pfound->flag) {
995  | 		*(pfound->flag) = pfound->val;
996  | 		return( 0);
997  | 	    }
998  | 	    return( pfound->val);
999  | 	}
1000 | 
1001 | 	/**
1002 | 	 **  Can't find it as a long option.  If this is not getopt_long_only,
1003 | 	 **  or the option starts with '--' or is not a valid short
1004 | 	 **  option, then it's an error.
1005 | 	 **  Otherwise interpret it as a short option. 
1006 | 	 **/
1007 | 
1008 | 	if( !long_only || argv[optind][1] == '-' ||
1009 | 	    my_index( optstring, *nextchar) == NULL) {
1010 | 
1011 | 	    if( opterr) {
1012 | 
1013 | 		/**
1014 | 		 ** ERROR: unrecognized --option 
1015 | 		 **/
1016 | 
1017 | 		if( argv[optind][1] == '-') {
1018 | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
1019 | 		    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_UNKNOWN, LOC, nextchar, NULL);
1020 | #else
1021 | 		    fprintf( stderr, _("%s: unrecognized option `--%s'\n"),
1022 | 			argv[0], nextchar);
1023 | #endif
1024 | 
1025 | 		/**
1026 | 		 ** ERROR: unrecognized +option or -option
1027 | 		 **/
1028 | 
1029 | 		} else {
1030 | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
1031 | 		    char buffer[ BUFSIZ];
1032 | 		    sprintf( buffer, "%c%s", argv[optind][0], nextchar);
1033 | 		    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_AMBIG, LOC, buffer, NULL);
1034 | #else
1035 | 		    fprintf( stderr, _("%s: unrecognized option `%c%s'\n"),
1036 | 			argv[0], argv[optind][0], nextchar);
1037 | #endif
1038 | 		}
1039 | 	    }
1040 | 
1041 | 	    nextchar =( char *) "";
1042 | 	    optind++;
1043 | 	    return( '?');
1044 | 	}
1045 |     } /** if( long option) **/
1046 | 
1047 |     /**
1048 |      **  Look at and handle the next short option-character. 
1049 |      **/
1050 | 
1051 |     {
1052 | 	char c = *nextchar++;
1053 | 	char *temp = my_index( optstring, c);
1054 | 
1055 | 	/**
1056 | 	 **  Increment `optind' when we start to process its last character. 
1057 | 	 **/
1058 | 
1059 | 	if( *nextchar == '\0')
1060 | 	    ++optind;
1061 | 
1062 | 	/**
1063 | 	 **  Unrecognized options
1064 | 	 **/
1065 | 
1066 | 	if( temp == NULL || c == ':') {
1067 | 	    if( opterr) {
1068 | 
1069 | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
1070 | 		    char buffer[ 2];
1071 | 		    buffer[ 0] = c;
1072 | 		    buffer[ 1] = '\0';
1073 | #endif
1074 | 
1075 | 		if( posixly_correct) {
1076 | 
1077 | 		    /**
1078 | 		     **  1003.2 specifies the format of this message. 
1079 | 		     **/
1080 | 
1081 | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
1082 | 		    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_ILL, LOC, buffer, NULL);
1083 | #else
1084 | 		    fprintf( stderr, _("%s: illegal option -- %c\n"),
1085 | 			argv[0], c);
1086 | #endif
1087 | 		} else {
1088 | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
1089 | 		    ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_INV, LOC, buffer, NULL);
1090 | #else
1091 | 		    fprintf( stderr, _("%s: invalid option -- %c\n"),
1092 | 			argv[0], c);
1093 | #endif
1094 | 		}
1095 | 	    }
1096 | 	    optopt = c;
1097 | 	    return( '?');
1098 | 	}
1099 | 
1100 | 	/**
1101 | 	 **
1102 | 	 **/
1103 | 
1104 | 	if( temp[1] == ':') {
1105 | 	    if( temp[2] == ':') {
1106 | 
1107 | 		/**
1108 | 		 **  This is an option that accepts an argument optionally.
1109 | 		 **/
1110 | 
1111 | 		if( *nextchar != '\0') {
1112 | 		    optarg = nextchar;
1113 | 		    optind++;
1114 | 		} else
1115 | 		    optarg = NULL;
1116 | 
1117 | 		nextchar = NULL;
1118 | 
1119 | 	    } else {	/** optional argument **/
1120 | 
1121 | 		/**
1122 | 		 **  This is an option that requires an argument. 
1123 | 		 **/
1124 | 
1125 | 		if( *nextchar != '\0') {
1126 | 		    optarg = nextchar;
1127 | 
1128 | 		    /**
1129 | 		     **  If we end this ARGV-element by taking the rest as an arg,
1130 | 		     **  we must advance to the next element now. 
1131 | 		     **/
1132 | 
1133 | 		    optind++;
1134 | 
1135 | 		} else if( optind == argc) {
1136 | 
1137 | 		    if( opterr) {
1138 | 
1139 | 			/**
1140 | 			 **  1003.2 specifies the format of this message. *
1141 | 			 **/
1142 | 
1143 | #ifdef	_MODULES_DEF_H
1144 | 			char buffer[ 2];
1145 | 			buffer[ 0] = c;
1146 | 			buffer[ 1] = '\0';
1147 | 			ErrorLogger( ERR_OPT_REQARG, LOC, buffer, NULL);
1148 | #else
1149 | 			fprintf( stderr,
1150 | 			    _("%s: option requires an argument -- %c\n"),
1151 | 				argv[0], c);
1152 | #endif
1153 | 		    }
1154 | 
1155 | 		    optopt = c;
1156 | 		    if( optstring[0] == ':')
1157 | 			c = ':';
1158 | 		    else
1159 | 			c = '?';
1160 | 
1161 | 		} else
1162 | 
1163 | 		    /**
1164 | 		     **  We already incremented `optind' once;
1165 | 		     **  increment it again when taking next ARGV-elt as argument.
1166 | 		     **/
1167 | 
1168 | 		    optarg = argv[optind++];
1169 | 		    nextchar = NULL;
1170 | 	    }
1171 | 	}
1172 | 
1173 | 	/**
1174 | 	 **  Now c contains the found character in case of success of '?' in case
1175 | 	 **  of failure
1176 | 	 **/
1177 | 
1178 | #ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
1179 | #  if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
1180 | 	ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_END, LOC, _proc_getopt_internal, NULL);
1181 | #  endif
1182 | #endif
1183 | 	return( c);
1184 | 
1185 |     } /** block **/
1186 | 
1187 | } /** End of '_getopt_internal' **/
1188 | 
1189 | /*++++
1190 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1191 |  ** 									     **
1192 |  **   Function:		getopt, getopt_long, getopt_long_only		     **
1193 |  ** 									     **
1194 |  **   Description:	Calls _getopt_internal in order to provide a normal  **
1195 |  **			getopt call.					     **
1196 |  ** 									     **
1197 |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **
1198 |  ** 									     **
1199 |  **   Parameters:	int	  argc,		# of arguments		     **
1200 |  **			char	**argv,		ARGV array		     **
1201 |  **			char 	 *optstring,	String of valid short opt.   **
1202 |  ** 									     **
1203 |  **   Result:		int	'?'	Parse error			     **
1204 |  **				0	Long option w/o argument found	     **
1205 |  **				else	short option that has been found     **
1206 |  **					or the value of a long option	     **
1207 |  **				EOF	no more arguments on ARGV	     **
1208 |  **									     **
1209 |  **   Attached globals:	optind		Index of the current option in the   **
1210 |  **					ARGV array			     **
1211 |  **			optarg		Argument of an option with value     **
1212 |  **			opterr		Set in case of parse errors	     **
1213 |  **									     **
1214 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1215 |  ++++*/
1216 | 
1217 | int getopt( int argc, char *const *argv, const char *optstring)
1218 | {
1219 | 
1220 | #ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
1221 | #  if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
1222 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_getopt, NULL);
1223 | #  endif
1224 | #endif
1225 | 
1226 |     return _getopt_internal( argc, argv, optstring,
1227 | 			     ( const struct option *) 0,
1228 | 			     ( int *) 0,
1229 | 			      0);
1230 | } /** End of 'getopt' **/
1231 | 
1232 | int getopt_long( int argc, char *const *argv, const char *optstring,
1233 | 		 const struct option *longopts, int *longind)
1234 | {
1235 | 
1236 | #ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
1237 | #  if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
1238 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_getopt_long, NULL);
1239 | #  endif
1240 | #endif
1241 | 
1242 |     return _getopt_internal( argc, argv, optstring, longopts, longind, 0);
1243 | 
1244 | } /** End of 'getopt' **/
1245 | 
1246 | int getopt_long_only( int argc, char *const *argv, const char *optstring,
1247 | 		      const struct option *longopts, int *longind)
1248 | {
1249 | 
1250 | #ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
1251 | #  if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
1252 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_getopt_long_only, NULL);
1253 | #  endif
1254 | #endif
1255 | 
1256 |     return _getopt_internal( argc, argv, optstring, longopts, longind, 1);
1257 | 
1258 | } /** End of 'getopt' **/
1259 | 
1260 | /* #endif	*/ /* _LIBC or not __GNU_LIBRARY__.  */
1261 | 
1262 | #ifdef TEST
1263 | 
1264 | /*++++
1265 |  ** ** Function-Header ***************************************************** **
1266 |  ** 									     **
1267 |  **   Function:		main						     **
1268 |  ** 									     **
1269 |  **   Description:	Test procedure for getopt			     **
1270 |  **			Compile with -DTEST to make an executable for use in **
1271 |  **			testing the above definition of `getopt'	     **
1272 |  ** 									     **
1273 |  **   First Edition:	1995/12/20					     **
1274 |  ** 									     **
1275 |  **   Parameters:	int	  argc,		# of arguments		     **
1276 |  **			char	**argv,		ARGV array		     **
1277 |  ** 									     **
1278 |  **   Result:		-						     **
1279 |  **									     **
1280 |  ** ************************************************************************ **
1281 |  ++++*/
1282 | 
1283 | int main( int argc, char **argv)
1284 | {
1285 | 
1286 | #  ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
1287 | #    if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
1288 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_START, LOC, _proc_main, NULL);
1289 | #    endif
1290 | #  endif
1291 | 
1292 |     int c;
1293 |     int digit_optind = 0;
1294 |     int longind;
1295 |     int option, verbose;
1296 |     char *value;
1297 | 
1298 |     const struct option longopts[] = {
1299 | 	{ "test", no_argument, NULL, 0 },
1300 | 	{ "option", optional_argument, &option, 1 },
1301 | 	{ "verbose", optional_argument, NULL, 'v' },
1302 | 	{ "value", required_argument, NULL, 'x'},
1303 | 	{ NULL, no_argument, NULL, 0 }
1304 |     };
1305 | 
1306 |     /**
1307 |      **  Print all options ...
1308 |      **/
1309 | 
1310 |     while( 1) {
1311 | 
1312 | 	int this_option_optind = optind ? optind : 1;
1313 | 
1314 | 	c = getopt_long( argc, argv, "abc:d:0123456789", longopts, &longind);
1315 | 	if( c == EOF)
1316 | 	    break;  /** while( 1) **/
1317 | 
1318 | 	switch( c) {
1319 | 
1320 | 	    case 0:
1321 | 		printf( "option --test or --option\n");
1322 | 		if( optarg)
1323 | 		    printf( "with argument '%s'", optarg);
1324 | 		printf( "\n   option is set to %d\n", option);
1325 | 		break;
1326 | 
1327 | 	    case '0':
1328 | 	    case '1':
1329 | 	    case '2':
1330 | 	    case '3':
1331 | 	    case '4':
1332 | 	    case '5':
1333 | 	    case '6':
1334 | 	    case '7':
1335 | 	    case '8':
1336 | 	    case '9':
1337 | 		if( digit_optind != 0 && digit_optind != this_option_optind)
1338 | 		    printf( "digits occur in two different argv-elements.\n");
1339 | 		digit_optind = this_option_optind;
1340 | 		    printf( "option %c\n", c);
1341 | 		break;
1342 | 
1343 | 	    case 'a':
1344 | 		printf( "option a\n");
1345 | 		break;
1346 | 
1347 | 	    case 'b':
1348 | 		printf( "option b\n");
1349 | 		break;
1350 | 
1351 | 	    case 'c':
1352 | 		printf( "option c with value `%s'\n", optarg);
1353 | 		break;
1354 | 
1355 | 	    case 'v':
1356 | 	    case 'x':
1357 | 		printf( "option %c ", c);
1358 | 		if( optarg)
1359 | 		    printf( "with argument '%s'", optarg);
1360 | 		printf( "\n");
1361 | 		break;
1362 | 
1363 | 	    case '?':
1364 | 		break;
1365 | 
1366 | 	    default:
1367 | 		printf( "?? getopt returned character code 0%o ??\n", c);
1368 | 	}
1369 |     }  /** while( 1) **/
1370 | 
1371 |     /**
1372 |      **  Finally print all remaining arguments
1373 |      **/
1374 | 
1375 |     if( optind < argc) {
1376 | 	printf( "non-option ARGV-elements: ");
1377 | 	while( optind < argc)
1378 | 	    printf( "%s ", argv[optind++]);
1379 | 	printf( "\n");
1380 |     }
1381 | 
1382 |     /**
1383 |      **  Exit on success
1384 |      **/
1385 | 
1386 | #  ifdef _MODULES_DEF_H
1387 | #    if WITH_DEBUGGING_INIT
1388 |     ErrorLogger( NO_ERR_END, LOC, _proc_main, NULL);
1389 | #    endif
1390 | #  endif
1391 | 
1392 |     exit( 0);
1393 | 
1394 | } /** End of 'main' **/
1395 | 
1396 | #endif /* TEST */
